results.title: Ring [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Omega Project, Ace Pictures, Shinya Kawai, Takashige Ichise, Takenori Sento and Hideo Nakata
results.brief_description: A chilling and atmospheric film delving into the devastating effects of human curiosity. Journalist Reiko Ashakawa (Nanako Matsushima) is investigating the credibility of claims that a “video curse” is linked to the gruesome deaths of groups of teenagers. An urban myth circulating among teenagers recounts tales of people dying exactly a week after viewing a videotape featuring a bizarre sequence of images. Reiko is drawn deeper into this mystery after her cousin Tomoko dies under sinister circumstances. When she learns that both Tomoko and Tomoko’s friend, who watched the eerie video together, died at exactly the same time, she begins to take the matter more seriously. Tracking down a copy of the tape, she suddenly finds that she has become the next victim of the “video curse”. Joining forces with her psychic ex-husband, Ryugi Takayama (Hiroyuki Sanada), Reiko is caught in a frantic race against time to save both herself and her son Yoichi (Rikiya Itaka), from the unseen evil that reaches out to them from beyond the grave. Based on a series of best-selling novels by Koji Suzuki, “Ring” signifies a shift toward a more sophisticated type of horror film which openly acknowledges the influence of Hollywood horror while taking it in an entirely different and unexpected direction.

results.title: Rikky and Pete = Rikky & Pete
results.creator_credit: Cascade Films, Nadia Tass and David Parker
results.brief_description: Rikky is a talented and would be singer and her brother, Pete, is a mechanical genius. After Pete pulls one practical joke too many, they escape Melbourne for an adventure in the outback eventually finding themselves amongst the characters of a mining town. Stars Stephen Kearney and Nina Landis with Bill Hunter, Bruno Lawrence and Bruce Spence in supporting roles.

results.title: Rikki -the Baby Monkey
results.brief_description: Produced to show young children how monkeys live in their native habitat. The story of baby Rhesus monkey, showing how the mother cares for the baby animal, foodstuffs preferred by monkeys, who the animals spend their rime climbing in the jungle.

results.title: Rikki-tikki-tavi
results.creator_credit: Chuck Jones Enterprises and Chuck Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Kipling classic from ‘The jungle books’”.
An animated version of Rudyard Kipling’s tale of a mongoose who is saved from a storm by a boy and his parents, and then becomes the family’s defender against the dreaded cobras that roam the compound. Narrated by Orson Welles. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Rigoletto
results.creator_credit: Excelsa Film, Grandi Film Storici, Giulio Fiaschi and Carmine Gallone
results.brief_description: Film version of Giuseppe Verdi’s tragic opera Rigoletto shot at the Teatro Dell’opera, Rome. This tale of revenge, rape and murder stars the highly acclaimed singer, Tito Gobbi in the role of Rigoletto supported by Mario Filippesche (Duke of Mantua), Anna Maria Canali (Maddalena) and Marcella Govoni acting in the role of Gilda with Lina Pagliughi singing the role of Gilda. Features the Chorus and Orchestra of Teatro Dell’opera, Rome, conducted by Tullio Serafin. Sung in Italian.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 3
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Included on the tape are: DUEL; A child who has been brainwashed with censored information to make him a model citizen rebels against all forms of censorship of the mind when he becomes an adult. NARCO BLUES; An ordinary teenager is unwillingly pulled into the harsh world of drugs. However an incident has a salutory effect on him. THE CORA PLAYER; Two young Africans from different social backgrounds defy tradition by falling in love. LOCKED; A boy is seized by an enormous hand that pushes him towards a hazardous lock factory- symobolizing innocence murdered by forced child labour. TRADE; A young Indian girl is sold by her parents to a pimp who takes her to work in a brothel. MASKS; Throughout childhood and adulthood a young man refuses to wear the “masks” imposed on him by social convention. DEATHTRAP; A young man closes all the doors to his heart, but seeing that suicide is a trap, decides to live. In English and French language.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 2
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the 1990 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Each film addresses a specific right that was agreed upon by the convention. They are designed to encourage children to think about the world in which they live. The films contain no dialogue. Part 2 is intended for children aged 9-12. The films are Jonas and Lisa” (dirs: Zabelle Cote, Daniel Schorr); “The Tournament (dir: Francine Desbiens); “Overdose” (dir: Claude Cloutier); “An artist” (Dir: Michele Cournoyer); “Baroque’n roll” (dir: Pierre M. Trudeau); “Ex-child” (dir: Jacques Drouin); “Why?” (dir: Bretislav Pojar). A resource guide for educators is included.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 1
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the 1990 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Each film addresses a specific right that was agreed upon by the convention. They are designed to encourage children to think about the world in which they live. They are also inspired by a range of posters from Pierre Post. The films contain no dialogue. “123 Coco” (dir. Pierre M. Trudeau): A young girl struggles in Maths but finally works it out thanks to visualisation. “Papa” (dir. Michele Pauze): The impressions of a young child as they wait for their busy father to play. “T.V. Tango” (dir. Martine Chartrand): A visual illustration of the influence of television on impressionable young minds. “The Orange = L’Orange” (dir: Diane Chartrand): A hungry boy reminisces about a wonderful orange he once had and a thoughtful teacher gives a valuable lesson in acceptance. “Door to door = Porte a porte” (dir: Zabelle Cote): When a class of young children are bullied by the older kids they pool their efforts to get some respect. “A Family for Maria = Une famille pour Maria” (dir. Lina Gagnon): A beggar girl finds herself adopted by a loving family but struggles to forget her past. “To see the world = Voir le monde” (dir: Francine Desbiens): Sleeping on a train a young boy is exposed to the hardships faced by children across the world.

results.title: Rights and wrongs (A)
results.creator_credit: University of Wollongong and Jane Innes
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The fourth episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the rights and guarantees for the population contained in the Australian Constitution and in tandem discusses past and present issues of Aboriginal reconciliation. At the opening of the program questions are put forward about the writing of the rights to be included in an altered Australian Constitution such as, should there be an entrenched Bill of Rights? Should there be a Statutory Bill of Rights? What other rights and guarantees should be written into the Constitution? Particular attention is also paid to the issues of Aboriginal reconciliation and how it should be written into and recognised in the Australian Constitution. This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Quentin Bryce, Professor John Goldring, Chief Justice Murray Gleeson, Helen Irving, Sue Tongue and Professor George Winterton.

results.title: Rights and responsibilities
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
This program is one of two dealing with politics in Australia during the course of this century. In “Rights and Responsibilities” the film segments have been selected to help students understand the Australian political process. Arranged in four themes, the program illustrates all levels in the political process. There are individuals fighting for their rights, pressure groups, society’s institutions, three levels of government, the monarchy and international relations.. Presented by Annette Shun Wah
